0.title: Find the bug: Inconsistent data-testid
0.description: One of the buttons has a data-testid that doesn't follow the established pattern. Identify which button has the inconsistent selector.
0.hint: Observe the challenge-option-X pattern in data-testids and look for the element that doesn't have a data-testid.
0.explanation: In automated testing, the absence of test identifiers is a critical problem that can cause intermittent failures and test instability. Elements without identifiers force the use of fragile selectors like CSS or XPath, which break easily when the interface changes. This results in unreliable tests, maintenance difficulties, and significant increase in debug time. Test identifiers (such as data-testid, data-cy, test-id, etc.) are essential because they are stable, expressive about the test's intent, and resistant to layout or style changes. A consistent identifier pattern ensures tests are robust and easy to maintain.

1.title: Accessibility - Contrast
1.description: Which of these color combinations does NOT meet the minimum WCAG contrast criteria?
1.hint: WCAG requires a minimum contrast ratio of 4.5:1 for normal text.
1.explanation: The combination of medium gray (#CBD5E0) on dark gray (#4A5568) has a contrast ratio of 2.9:1, below the minimum 4.5:1 required by WCAG 2.1. Good contrast is essential to ensure that all users, including those with low vision or color blindness, can read content easily. You can check contrast ratios using tools like WebAIM Contrast Checker or the WAVE browser plugin.

2.title: HTML Semantics
2.description: Identify the element that violates accessibility best practices:
2.hint: Native HTML elements are always preferable to custom elements with ARIA.
2.explanation: Using <div> with role='button' is less accessible than a native <button>, as it loses accessibility features and keyboard navigation.

3.title: Web Performance
3.description: Which metric is NOT part of Core Web Vitals?
3.hint: Core Web Vitals focuses on three main aspects: loading, interactivity, and visual stability.
3.explanation: Time to Interactive (TTI) is not part of Core Web Vitals, which are the three main Google metrics for measuring user experience: LCP, FID, and CLS.

4.title: API Testing - Status Code
4.description: Which HTTP status is most appropriate for a successful creation request?
4.hint: Think about the difference between a generic success response (200) and a specific one for creation.
4.explanation: Status 201 Created is most appropriate to indicate that a resource was successfully created in a POST request.

5.title: ARIA Labels
5.description: Which element has unnecessary accessibility redundancy?
5.hint: ARIA labels should complement, not duplicate information already present.
5.explanation: Using aria-label on an image that already has alt is redundant and can confuse screen readers.

6.title: Form Validation
6.hint: Think about format validations and possible values.
6.explanation: Date 31/02/2024 is invalid because February has at most 29 days (in leap year).

7.title: Regression Testing
7.description: Which type of test is NOT suitable for automation?
7.hint: Some tests require human creativity and adaptation.
7.explanation: Exploratory tests are based on tester experience and creativity, making them difficult to automate effectively.

8.title: SEO and Accessibility
8.description: Which element harms both SEO and accessibility?
8.hint: Think about elements that are not semantic but try to simulate semantics.
8.explanation: Using <div> with 'heading' class harms SEO (crawlers don't recognize as title) and accessibility (screen readers don't identify as heading).

9.title: Lighthouse Performance
9.description: Which metric does NOT directly impact Lighthouse score?
9.hint: Lighthouse focuses on user experience metrics.
9.explanation: Number of DOM elements is not a Lighthouse metric, which focuses on LCP, FID, CLS, FCP, and TBT.
